moves.1. d4: I'm playing black and I'm using the "Fisher" (Reti) opening again.
moves.6... dxe5: If white takes the pawn, it opens up the early queen exchange.
moves.7. dxe5: It's always a tough decision to exchange queens, but I must have been happy with my early castle and feeling confident about my chances, so I take his queen.
moves.7... Qxd1+ 8. Nxd1: White wisely preserves his ability to castle.
moves.8... Ng4:
Pressuring the e5 pawn.  I expect a pawn attack, which would result in stacked pawns.
9. e6 Bxe6
10. Bxe6 fxe6
moves.9. Bf4: I get a bit lucky in that he chooses to defend the e5 pawn.
moves.10. O-O Ngxe5:
A no brainer.  Go up one.  I fantasize about exchanges ...
11. Nxe5 Nxe5
12. Bxe5 Bxe5
13. c3 b6
14. Bd5 Rb8
... but he recognizes the situation.
moves.11. Nd2: I look at this now, and I wonder why I didn't exchange the bishop for a knight, but I must have seen the chaos of a pair of knights in the middle of the board.  (I doubt I actually knew how successful this next move would be, but maybe by subconscious knew.)  :-)
moves.11... Nd4 12. c3 Nxc4:
I set up a trap.  I expect ...
13. Nxc4 Ne2 
14. Kh1 Nxf4 ( 4)
moves.13... Nxd2 14. Bxd2 Bxd4: My big trap didn't work, but the small one does.  I'm still up 2 points and move into conservative play.
moves.15. Bb4 c5: I get lucky and he lets me gain a tempo.
moves.16. Bd2 Bg4 17. Nc3: Up 2 points, I'll take a trade, even a knight for a bishop.
moves.17... Bxc3 18. Bxc3: Here, I should be thinking about moving pieces into white squares where possible.
moves.24. f3 Ra6 25. Bh4 f6 26. Re4 Rd2 27. Rb: A lucky break again, the pressure on the b2 pawn sets up diagonally stacked rooks.
moves.27... Bf5 28. Rxe7 Bxb1 29. b3 Rd1+:
I'm expecting a block.  
30. Be1 cxb3
moves.30. Kh2 c3 31. Re1 c2 32. Rxd1 cxd1=Q 33: A little late game sloppiness here, but no great harm.
moves.36. gxf6 Qxf6 37. h4 Qxh4+ 38. Kg2 Bxb3: Avoid the stalemate, keep him in check.

gameName: Fisher/Reti for black, beware of a pair of knights in the middle of the board
